ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: This is the first year this course was taught and as such, it was a great success. I expect that it will only improve each time it's offered. That said, people considering the class should thoroughly read the student comments to get a feel for the pros and cons of the class.
Fantastic readings!
The teaching style and the synergy between the instructors, which made the discussions very fruitful and enjoyable.
The discussion which was very pleasant and interesting. The instructors made sure everyone got to talk.
Needed a readings based course like this to get a better base of environmental thought.

The enthusiasm of Professors Tucker and Grim. They are truly committed to teaching. The breadth and depth of their knowledge is impressive. This course is also valuable because it allows students to explore their passion for the environment through the written word. This class is about the poetry, about the awesomeness of nature. It's a great complement to the science heavy curriculum at FES.
The reading assignments.
Some of the readings exposed me to environmental writers with whom I was previously unfamiliar.
The readings were the best part of the course. They were an excellent selection of the best and most important environmental writers/thinkers.

The professors! They are gifted with a beautiful sense of pleasantness, kindness, insightfulness, and care. They are literally the best professors i have had at Yale so far, and perhaps even throughout my whole life -they are certainly gifted. I have taken a course with Dr. Grim last semester, and having taken two courses under him and one course under Dr. Tucker, i can honestly say that they are one of the greatest assets of F&ES, if not the university altogether. I believe we can all learn from them.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: More tightly organized class time - stay on point and on schedule to get through all readings.
I wouldn't recommend any improvements.
I wanted more "great books" typesof readings with a much stronger historical thread. It was more of a sampling of various ideas and movements, but not necessarily in a historical context.

The class would benefit from fewer but deeper readings or, if not that, discussions that focus on one or two authors instead of all the reading we did.There also seems to be an emphasis on values as opposed to history. This may be because the professors are scholars of religion so values are extremely important to them.Too much emphasis on worldly wonder.Though I can't imagine this would be an issue in years to come, the over-emphasis on the film produced by the professors was a distracting turn of events during the course. The persistent effort to make the course about the film hurt our efforts to deepen our understanding of environmental history and values. It was also uncomfortable, and even unethical, to be asked to provide reviews of the film.

Journey of the Universe was interesting but it received too much attention in the second half of the semester. It was interesting to talk about for one class but became a distraction to the other material.

Too superficial of a course. We read tiny excerpts from great works by environmental writers, philosophers, poets, activists, etc., but were assigned too many each week. It would have been so much better to have read one full work per week and to discuss in detail with historical context. The class was fairly light on history.

It is critical to have less students in this class. We had too many students and it hurt the discussion. It might be worth not having undergrads in the class. Many of us wished we had more lecture time from Mary Evelyn and John, and less open discussion. ME and John seemed more interested in making sure everyone spoke than guiding a productive discussion. Discussions sometimes felt all over the place. After three hours the discussion would be dried up and become tedious at times. Perhaps it would be better to have two 1.5-hour classes each week - one would be a proper lecture by the prof's and the other would be open discussion. Mary Evelyn and John are such amazing thinkers -- I wanted to hear more from them. I wanted to hear more about the actual HISTORY and context of these writers, and less from students about their personal opinions regarding the books/writings. I think it should be made clearer that there will be a lot of religion/philosophy discussion. Lastly, the course sort of fell apart right when ME and John were launching their film Journey of the Universe. They were clearly consumed by the film project. Although the film was never marked as required material for the course, it DOMINATED class time towards the end. How can we give honest and open critique/discussion of the film when it's clearly the baby of the professors?
Perhaps a field trip for next year would be fun to have.

Very unprofessional to emphasize your film project so much and to make it a basis for a final question.Also, you should not accept so many undergrads into the class. Made the class discussions shallow, boring, and unproductive.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: TA - Jason - super responsive. Professors great too.
Both instructors were always approachable and helpful; the TA could have participated more in the class discussions.
I never contacted the TA but the instructors were always available and more than willing to help.
Great
I never needed either but they seemed completely available.
Great facilitation of discussion sections.
TA was responsive.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I think this kind of course should be taken by everyone first semester. We weren't all environmental studies majors in college. Discussing the big ideas and their evolution with your classmates would be vital. Maybe no papers though.
A great complement to the physical and social science classes that dominate the curriculum. It's a humanities class; the professors are clear on this point and proud of it.
I think everyone should take a course from these amazing profs. And these readings should be required for any environmental student.

This course directly relates to my overall program. Dr. Tucker and Dr. Grim bring something very unique to F&ES, and i am very grateful that we have such wonderful classes on religion and ecology or american environmental history and values available to us at F&ES. Indeed, their presence at F&ES has changed my trajectory to something i feel much more connected to. I strongly recommend more of a F&ES focus on things to do with what Dr. Tucker and Dr. Grim teach.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Like the professors, interested in American Environmental History.
To get a better understanding of the influential figures behind the environmentalism movement.
To learn more about the thinkers that shaped the environmental movement.
To deepen my knowledge of American Envtl History.

Though it would provide a rich foundation in the tradition of which I consider myself a part--how did thinking about the environment evolve in the U.S.? How did management evolve? How did these trends coincide to events of the time? Can we use this to better understand why we are facing the problems we are today?
I wanted an opportunity to read these amazing authors/books/writings.

Both the professors and the topic of the course. As said, i strongly recommend more of a F&ES focus on what Dr. Tucker and Dr. Grim teach -as opposed to it being on the periphery of the school's work. With that said, i certainly am grateful for their presence at the school.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes.
Yes
More history would have been good.
Mostly.
No.
Yes.
It certainly surpassed!

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes.
Yes
Yes
Somewhat. Too much emphasis on values and too little on history.
No.
I don't think I was expecting religion to be such a major component of the course. I wanted more historical context for the authors/writings.
Much more :)

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: The professors offerred us the opportunity to help out with the Journey of the Universe showing and conference, and it was a great and unique opportunity.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Definitely take this class if you are interested in the more spiritual and history-related aspects of environmental management. It opens up your perspective to different thoughts and academic fields and the discussions are great.
Take this class as a humanities complement to your other classes. It's great to explore the creativity of authors inspired by nature.

I really enjoyed the course, the reading list was amazing, Prof. Grim and Tucker are fantastic and lead great discussions, and the diversity of students taking the course exceeded most I've taken (Divinity, FES, Public Health, Yale College, etc) adding depth tothe discussions.
If you do take this course, push for the syllabus to be changed to focus on fewer figures but in more depth. Or pick one writer per week and just read the entire text instead of the excerpt assigned.
Interact with the professors outside of the classroom :)
